captions.text: LARRY: What's up, guys?
Larry here from ammonyc.com .

So a few weeks ago for our
episode on rim repair, we

visited George at Proformance
Industries.

As we saw in that episode,
George is a true metallurgist,

an expert at bending and
reshaping metal.

On today's episode, we're going
to be partnering again

with George to show you what
really happens in the elusive

skill of PDR, or Paintless
Dent Removal.

That's all coming up on this
episode of "Drive Clean,"

right here on the
Drive Network.
All right, George.

So my car has a lot
of dings in it.

And I've always wanted to know
what is actually going on
during the PDR process.

GEORGE: Imagine this is
the hood of your car.
Impact comes in.
You see what just happened?
This pillow folded.

LARRY: Yeah, these sides
popped up here.
GEORGE: Exactly.

So to the naked eye, it just
looks like a low spot.

But really what's happening is
you're impacting the metal.

The sides of it are
crowning up.

So to fix this properly,
what we need to do--

we don't want to stretch
this metal.

So we need to bring this down
a little, bring this up a
little bit, down, up.

LARRY: Because in reality, I
always thought you guys were
just popping it up.
GEORGE: No.

LARRY: You're really focusing
on the outer edges of the
actual impact.
Does that make sense?
GEORGE: Exactly.

And that understanding is the
major difference between the

really top-notch PDR technician
and the average PDR
technician.

The average PDR technician
is pushing out, trying
to force this out.

And the really savvy,
experienced PDR technician

understands this concept and
fixes these dents totally
undetectable.

Some guys fix them, and
they look pretty good.
But it's still not perfect.

LARRY: So if this went in and
you just focused on pulling

that out without doing these,
what does it look like
afterwards?
Is it just wavy?

GEORGE: What would happen is
you would need tremendous

force to get this
center section
out beyond this outside.

And you would end up stretching
it and leaving
these little tiny poke marks.
LARRY: Yeah.
I've seen that before.
GEORGE: Yeah.

So we want to manipulate this
metal, and never really push

with more force than the texture
of the orange peel.

So if we do push, we want to
make these little movements.

But with that amount of force
I'm describing, you'd never

get this out without relieving
the stress around the outside.
LARRY: Gotcha.

GEORGE: So it's important to
understand this concept before
we tackle this dent.

Traditional auto body repair
is done on a feel basis.
PDR is done on a visual basis.

So we need to create
a reference point.
Now, the props that you see--
boards similar to this--

are no different than the
fluorescent light fixture on
your ceiling.

Anything that you can drag your
eye across that's fixed,

that we can judge the contour
of this panel and see its

irregularities, would be
a good reference point.
That light fixture actually--

I'm looking at the reflection
of that light fixture.

And I see every crevice
and contour and shape
of this dent perfectly.
However, my reference point--

I need to be able to move
it at different angles.

Because I can fix this
dent according to
that reference point.

But then when I look
from your--
LARRY: Yeah.

I can't see what you're
seeing right now.

GEORGE: --from your side,
at different degrees.

So this dent, I need to be able
to fix it 360 degrees
from every angle.

Once we get to that point where
we think we've fixed it

perfectly, we can go
from another angle
and check and verify.

But this is for us to see the
tip of the tool underneath
this panel.

As we're dragging, the tool
needs to drag across this.

If we didn't, we wouldn't be
able to gauge where we were on
the back side of this panel.

LARRY: So without this board,
you would say--

how ineffective is it
to remove a dent?
Like, almost impossible?

GEORGE: Without a good reference
point, I'd be
probably as effective as you.
No offense.

So my 20 years experience in
this, without this board set

up properly, without a good
reference point, I'm useless.

I'd be guessing where the
tip of this tool is.
LARRY: Gotcha.

GEORGE: I'm trying to explain,
as best I can, the most

effective way to set up
a reference point.

So this being our reference
point, imagine this was the
dent on your hood.

Imagine there's all sheet
metal around here.
This is a--
LARRY: Blown-up dent--
GEORGE: --blown-up dent.

Well, if I had this reference
point, can you see--

I want you to look
into this panel.

Because it's very important when
we're fixing these dents

that you see the full contour
and the shape of
the dent at all times.
Could you see?

LARRY: From right here,
I can't see the
middle of the dent.
GEORGE: Right.

So we need that reference point
in the beginning stages
of repairing this dent.
We need it.

Now if you looked in that
dent, you could see that
reflection.
LARRY: Yeah.
Absolutely.
Yeah.

GEORGE: So that's
very important.
LARRY: I can see this.

GEORGE: That's very important
when we start fixing a dent.

And we want to be able
to see the tip of our
tool in that dent.

LARRY: So from the back
side of this,
feeling around the metal--
GEORGE: Exactly.

Because it's very easy to
see the tip of the tool.

I could teach you in a couple
minutes to see the tip of the
tool on a flat panel.

And you can see, track
it where it's going.

Oh, it's going to
be pretty easy.

But when we have a dent, the
material's not flexible

anymore, like straight
sheet metal.
So it gets some rigidity.

So we need to know exactly where
we are when we get to
the edge of this panel.

And then with a real focused
eye, see that tip of that

tool, train our eye to
see that in the dent.

It's very important that we see
all these pressure points.
Because this dent now--

contrary to what people may
believe, to fix a dent like

this, we will make
a push here.
We'll make a push here.

We'll make a push here, here,
here, here, here.

So just this region here,
we might have had--
this is real world.

This little section
right here--

LARRY: You would have pushed
from behind, you mean.

GEORGE: I would have pushed
from behind--

LARRY: Little push, little
push, little push--

GEORGE: --first at the lowest
point and softening the dent.

When I've softened this center
section, the deepest point of

this dent, I'll go back to my
reference point from a sharp

angle and maybe do the same
process on the outside of

those crowns that bulged up that
I showed you before in
the pillow.

LARRY: They would be
here, in theory?

GEORGE: Out here I would go and
press down and knock down
those crowns.

The best repairs are where the
surface area is consistent.
We brought this down.
We brought this out.
We didn't stretch anything.
Let's do it.

The first thing we're going to
do is just mark off this area.
You got that dent right there.

So I'm going to circle this so
you can keep an eye on the
center of that.
Here's your dent.

So when we're doing paintless
dent removal, leverage is very

important in enabling us to have
good control of the tool.

So we want to create a pivot
point somewhere close to the

dent and work off of
that pivot point.

So what I'm going to do here is
just put this old block of

wood here, and then get
a piece of wire,
maybe tie it off here.

And I'm going to use the
vinyl-coated wire, like
electrical wire.

Because if you miss and you hit
this car, at least it's
got a vinyl coating.

We're not going to scratch
up the car.
So I'm going to tie this off.
LARRY: So now this-- oh, yeah.
GEORGE: Well, it's movable.

But just gauging my leverage, I
think it's pretty darn good.
I'm going to move this over.

Now I'm going to set up
my reference point.
OK.

So I feel pretty comfortable
with that positioning.
But I'm going to--

I don't know if you're going
to be able to see this.

But what I'm going to do right
now is drag the tip of my tool

this way on this panel, across
this reference point.

So I'm looking at the reflection
of this dent on the

edge of the yellow and
the black line.

LARRY: How do you know
where your point is?

GEORGE: I'm going to
drag it across.

And the line, when
I drag across
this line, will distort.

It'll show me exactly
where I am.

I mean, that's close to
20 pushes already
for that little dent.
I used a very blunt tool.
I used a sharper tool.
We could have got away with--

but I wanted you to see exactly
how the metal reacts.

And this was an extreme case
because this has a sound

deadening on the back
side, which blunts.
And this is a very blunt tip.

So what happened is I can't make
a sharp pinpoint pushing
the center of that dent.

So I brought up this
whole area.

But now, you can see clearly
what I was explaining to you.

If you look, you see
a crown with a
little pit in the middle.
LARRY: Yup.
It does look like a volcano.
GEORGE: Right.

So for me to get that little
pit out right now, I would
need to continue to stretch.
But I stopped.

Because I recognized
that crown.
I said, whoa.

Let me knock down that crown,
soften it again, and bring out
the center again.

So that's what we're
going to do.

So it almost looks like I
put the dent back in.

It's just a very smaller version
of the original dent.

What happened was I just
softened this dent.

So from this little sharp
dent, I brought it out,
brought it out.

Now I just have a shallower,
softer, dent.
So now I'll go back in there.

It's five pushes already
for that little thing.
All right.

At this reference point, I'm
pretty comfortable where we
are so far.

We need to knock down
a little bit more.

All right, for this last step,
Larry, because this car has

been repainted and there is
a little impression in the

paint, we're going
to wet sand it.

I just got a little 2,000 grit
wet sandpaper with a little
rubber squeegee.

And if there was a chip in this
paint, this would be a
great time to touch this up.

There are literally these tiny
little shiny spots where the

sand hit the paint,
flattened it.

This car would really do well
with a nice wet sand and

polish to take out
all that stuff.
Because it didn't go through.

So here I go in a little
different direction now.
Once again, no pressure.

LARRY: Depending if your paint
is hard or soft, you may need

to finish your wet sanding at
2,500 or even 3,000 grit

instead of the 2,000
shown here.

GEORGE: The squeegee does a
really nice job of removing
all the water.

And this process, what it does
is-- see those little, tiny

spots, little, tiny,
shiny, spots?
Those are--
I didn't sand far enough.
So this is a real great guide.

You can see that little
impression that
we had in the paint?
Visually, we saw it.

I made a little,
tiny poke mark.

All I did was manipulate
the existing
material that was there.

So if this was a 3 mil thickness
of primer, paint,

and clear coat, all we did was
kind of distorted that

material to give us enough
room to sand it flush and
re-polish it.
Because the dent was fixed.
We've addressed this issue.

We don't see any shiny spots,
which would be a low spot.

It's consistently
sanded smooth.

This dent is ready
for polishing.

LARRY: Afterwards, I followed up
the wet sanding with 2,500

grit to allow the Rupes polisher
and the microfiber

cutting pad to easily repair
the sanding marks.

I'm using the Rupes polisher on
speed six, medium to heavy

pressure, along with leveling
fluid in a crisscross pattern.

Remember, most body shops will
use a rotary polisher, along

with a wool pad, for its speed
and cutting power.

And there's nothing
wrong with that.

But because this Porsche's
black--

and of course, I'm
the lucky owner--

I don't mind spending an extra
minute or two to avoid

potential burn-through
or swirl marks.

As you can see, the dent was
removed by manipulating the

metal from below and the top
side, allowing it to slowly

bend back into a smooth, flat
surface, saving me from a
costly body shop visit.

Paintless dent removal requires
a sharp eye, steady

hand, and an incredible amount
of knowledge surrounding the

properties of metal, and
how to manipulate--

or bend-- it-- without
causing more damage.

As long as cars have doors,
doors will most definitely
have dings.

And thankfully, PDR technicians
will magically

make them disappear with just a
few hundred small pushes in
the exact right spot.
George is a metallurgy master.

The before and after on my
hood is just incredible.

There's literally no evidence
of any dings.

For a PDF download of our
recommended tips for finding

high-quality paint dent removal
technicians, visit
ammonyc.com.

And thanks again for watching
another episode of "Drive
Clean."
[LARRY AND GEORGE CHATTING]

GEORGE: We don't want
to go too far.

That's why I'm being
so careful.

Because we have no
real access--

very tight access from the
back side to the--
LARRY: Oh, from the back--
can't push it out.

title: Paintless Dent Repair on a Porsche 911 -- /DRIVE CLEAN

comments.text:
Of course PDR professionals are going to say "Leave it to the 
professionals, not a DIY project" If you can do it, I can do it... While it 
may take me a while to get there, but it's not exactly rocket science on 
how to do this stuff... It just takes practice and research... Just like 
everything else in this world.﻿
comments.author: Surakusa

comments.text:
+ChasingTruth TakingFlak Keep on chasing, I guess. 
https://yourlogicalfallacyis.com/slippery-slope
comments.author: Brad Burson

comments.text: Totally agree with you.
comments.author: ctjbonner

comments.text:
+ChasingTruth TakingFlak
1. It's the internet, nobody is perfect, I really don't care.
2. See number one.
3. I didn't say you shouldn't pay for anything, I just simply stated that 
if you want to really learn something, you can. 

For example, years ago, I was told that I shouldn't try to rebuild the 
engine in my car and I should just pay to have someone do it for me which 
would cost roughly around 6k as quoted from one of my local mechanics. I'm 
sure we can all agree that if your car is about 10 years old, it's just not 
worth having it professionally done unless it has some sentimental value. 
So instead, I decided to take the initiative, and learn a skill. I spent a 
heck of a lot less rebuilding that engine than what I was originally 
quoted, and it has been running great ever since. Now I may had to purchase 
tools, an engine hoist, and a few parts. In the long run, now that I know 
how to fix my own car. I will continue to save a lot of money till the day 
I die... The only price I really pay is my time. But for myself, I really 
enjoy working on these sort of things so time is not a factor for me. Also 
when it comes to PDR, while yes I agree with you, it will probably take 5+ 
years to be an "expert", expert level really has to do with the ability to 
handle just about any dent which you gain through experience, but the most 
common dents are ones that are quarter-sized. Which in my opinion, doesn't 
require a huge amount of expertise. There are tons of ways to practice in 
order to get real-world experience. But in any case, I'm sure you don't 
care, and you will continue to bash my dreadful grammar. I wish the best of 
luck to you.
comments.author: Surakusa

comments.text:
Of course suspension engineers are going to say "Leave it to the 
professionals, not a DIY project" If they can do it, I can do it... While 
it may take me a while to get there (5+ years of on-job experience and 
equipment costing more than the cost of my car), but it's not exactly 
rocket science on how to do that stuff... It just takes practice and 
research (and money)... Just like everything else in this world.

1. An ellipsis is not followed by a space
2. Don't use an ellipsis instead of a period.
3. By the logic you used in your comment, nobody should pay for anything, 
everyone should just become experts in everything.

You want coffee? Better start cultivating the beans.
You need a greenhouse to cultivate? Better learn how to manufacture glass, 
sealant, and fittings.
You need fertilizer to cultivate? Better learn how to synthesize ammonia.
You need a thermostat and humidifier to cultivate? Better learn how to 
build circuitry and program.
You need materials for that circuitry? Better learn how to process copper 
and rubber.

And so forth.
comments.author: ChasingTruth TakingFlak

comments.text:
Great video! Love the explanation with the pillow and all, thanks for 
sharing.﻿
comments.author: Doug Miller

comments.text:
Wow George, you've got a knack for explaining the PDR process, the visuals 
are great and the explanations are spot on. There are two things that are 
missing in this video...1.) Not for the DYI person, This is better left to 
the professionals, and 2.) there are a ton of tools out there now that you 
might not be aware of that would definitely in the last 5 or so years that 
would make your job a lot easier and consistent. We all get use to the 
tools we've been using since we started years ago.
comments.author: Vince DAlessandro

comments.text: VERY DIFFICULT get a quality tech for that!
comments.author: llaracuente

comments.text:
it depends on the size location and ease of access. a dent can cost 40-400 
dollars depending on the above factors.a typical door ding the size of a 
quarter could run you about (ball park) 60-80 dollars. when it comes to pdr 
you get what you pay for. don't just go with anyone. inexperienced techs 
can make the dent worse. good luck

comments.text:
While I appreciate the guy's passion in his craft, if he was better (and

area. He seriously needs to upgrade some of his equipment too.
